abstract.para: To change kernel boot parameters persistently for all subsequent boot processes, edit the kernel parameters using &yastcc; as root or an user with equivalent administrative privileges.

example.title: Permanently modify kernel boot parameters using &yastcc;
example.para: As an example of modifying kernel boot parameters persistently for all subsequent boot process, we disable the splash screen that you can see during the boot.

warning.para: Before modifying kernel boot parameters, create a copy of the existing stable &grub; configuration (/etc/default/grub) somewhere outside of your system. If the boat loader gets corrupted and your system fails to boot, or you face problems after booting your system, the back up helps you compare and restore the parameters to the last known working configuration.

step.para: Log in to your system as root, or switch to a user with equivalent administrative privileges after logging in to your system.

Alternatively, open the &yastcc; application and select SystemBoot Loader.
Under the Kernel Parameters tab, edit the string for the Optional Kernel Command Line Parameter field.
As you can see, the string splash=silent is printed. Remove splash=silent from the string.
Select OK to save the boot loader configuration.
Reboot. You should see that the splash screen does not appear.

example.para: After executing the procedure and rebooting the system, we do not observe any splash screen for all subsequent boot process.

note.title: Editing the &grub; configuration file
note.para: If you directly edit the /etc/default/grub file, modify the GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX or GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX_DEFAULT variables. After modification, regenerate the &grub; configuration by running the following command with administrative privileges.
